title-group.article-title: Is Intention to Return a Valid Proxy for Actual Repeat Visitation?

article-meta.aff: 1The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Kowloon, Hong Kong

author-notes.corresp: Bob McKercher, Professor, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hung Hom, Kowloon, Hong Kong Email: hmbob@polyu.edu.hk

abstract.p: Intention to return is often used as a surrogate measure for actual repeat propensity, especially in loyalty studies. A direct, predictive correlation is assumed to exist between intention and actual repeat visitation rates in accordance with the principles of the theory of planned behavior. However, the existence of such a relationship has rarely if ever been tested empirically in a tourism context, and as such, the validity of this assumption is open to question. This article examines that relationship through an analysis of secondary data provided by a number of National Tourism Organizations. Two tests are conducted, one using longitudinal data from 30 markets that visited either Hong Kong or New Zealand, and a second one using cross-sectional data from 152 markets that visited 16 destinations. The study determined that no statistically significant correlation exists between intention and actual repeat visitation rates, primarily because intention is typically measured as a vague aspiration and not in a probabilistic manner.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Destinations are encouraged to measure tourists’ intention to return for many reasons (Aasaker, Esposito Vinzi, and O’Connor 2011; Yun et al. 2007), including the belief that they are a valid surrogate for predicting actual repeat propensity (Hong et al. 2009). This belief is predicated on the theories of planned behavior and/or reasoned action (TPB or TRA), where a relationship is believed to exist between service quality, satisfaction, and future behavioral intentions (Brencic and Dmitrovic 2010; Chi and Qu 2008; March and Woodside 2005; Yoon and Uysal 2005). Prayag (2009) notes that tourism studies examining behavioral intentions have reached a general consensus that satisfied visitors will come back and will tell others about their favorable experiences. Sutton (1998) supports this argument in principle, for he notes that without intentions people will not act. Likewise, much tourism research examining destination loyalty, or extending satisfaction to an actionable outcome also uses intentions as a measure. Justification is provided either by citing studies undertaken in a nontourism context (Bigne, Sanchez, and Sanchez 2001; Lennon, Weber, and Henson 2001) or by referring to other tourism studies that have used this metric (Alegre and Cladera 2006; Kim 2008; Kozak and Rimmington 2000).

Little empirical evidence testing the strength of the relationship and its predictive ability have been published though. Its veracity is simply assumed, even though some question whether such a relationship does indeed exist (Caneem 2003; Mechinda, Serirat, and Guild 2009). This article seeks to stimulate discussion about the validity of intention to return as a proxy for repeat visitation rates by analyzing two types of secondary data generated by a number of national tourism organizations (NTOs) that have measured intention to return and actual repeat visitation rates. The authors acknowledge that the use of secondary data represents an indirect method to test the relationship. However, this technique can still be used to raise important questions about the relationship, at least at an aggregate level, especially in the absence of reliable, longitudinal primary data sets.

sec.title: Prevalence and Presumed Validity of Intentions as a Surrogate for Repeat Visitation
sec.p: A review of the Scholar.Google database was undertaken to document how frequently intent to return is used in studies examining destination satisfaction, loyalty, or repeat visitation. Keywords used included destination loyalty, tourist loyalty, tourist satisfaction, predicting repeat behaviour, and loyalty tourism. This data set was augmented by the list of tourism loyalty articles identified by McKercher, Denizci-Guillet, and Ng (2011). The method section of each article was reviewed to determine how loyalty or repeat usage was measured. A total of 50 articles were identified. Forty-two measured intention to repeat/revisit, alone or in conjunction with other measures (See Table 1). Willingness to recommend was used most frequently when combined with intention (e.g., Bosnjak et al. 2011; Chen and Tsai 2007; McDowall 2010; Yuksel 2001) in accordance with accepted protocols used to measure loyalty. Only eight articles did not use intentions as a measure. Six measured attitudinal loyalty exclusively (willingness to recommend), while two focused on actual repeat visitation rates. In all cases where intentions were measured, it is assumed implicitly or stated explicitly that intentions act as a valid predictor of actual repeat visitation rates. Sutton (1998), though, cautions that prediction and explanation are not the same and that prediction can lead to false positive results.

sec.p: Tourism loyalty research tends to adopt frameworks applied in nontourism settings (Barsky and Nash 2002; Mason, Tideswell, and Roberts 2006; Oppermann 1999; Westwood et al. 1999) without considering the unique nature of tourism. Scholars borrowing existing models typically point to evidence that establishes the link between intention and subsequent behavior (Alegre and Cladera 2006, 2009; Chen and Tsai 2007; Chi and Hu 2007; Oom de Valle et al. 2006; Jang and Feng 2007; Lee 2009; Prayag 2009). Bigne, Sanchez, and Sanchez (2001) illustrate that the literature on marketing has shown a positive relationship between quality, intention, and repurchase. Alegre and Cladera (2009) refer to numerous studies in the marketing literature. Mechinda, Serirat, and Guild (2009) point to consumer research conducted in 1995 that confirms a strong link between intent to repurchase and repurchase behaviors. Yun et al. (2007), summarizing the literature, indicate that studies elsewhere have shown correlations between intentions and subsequent behavior ranging from 0.69 to 0.90, while Jang and Feng (2007) and others cite the relatively strong predictive reliability found in the meta analysis of past research documented by Sheppard, Hartwick, and Warchaw (1988) as evidence of the applicability of intention to action.

However, it is apparent that the sources cited by these and other authors are used in a rather selective manner, for a more thorough review of these works reveals that the authors came to equivocal conclusions about the link. For example, while Sheppard, Hartwick, and Warchaw’s (1998) work is often cited, researchers generally fail to mention the three critical qualifying conditions they identified that can significantly affect the intentions–actions relationship: the impact of intervening factors; the decaying effect caused by increased choice; and how intent is measured. Other meta-analytic studies have produced no conclusive evidence of an absolute link between intent and action. Conner and Armitage (1998), for example, concluded that studies of the theory of reasoned actions accounted for 38% of the variance in behavior, while a meta-analysis of the theory of planned behavior indicate that intentions account for only 34% of behavior. Sutton (1998) came to similar conclusions, finding correlations ranging from 0.44 to 0.62, or explaining only between 19% and 38% of variance.

In fact, Sutton (1998) identifies nine reasons why such a link may be tenuous. Many are relevant to this article. To begin, intentions may change over time, with the longer the gap between intention and future behavior, the greater the likelihood of change. Venkatesh, Maruping, and Brown (2006) support this claim, while a study by Sniehotta, Scholz, and Schwarzer (2005) examining the adoption and maintenance of physical exercise among cardiac patients indicated that intentions accounted for a diminishing 23% of the variance noted in actual exercise activity within a relatively short 6 to 10 weeks. This issue is especially prescient in tourism when purchases tend to be infrequent. Aasaker, Vinzi, and O’Connor (2011) and Jang and Feng (2007) evaluated intent to revisit on three time scales (immediate, midterm, and long term) and found an inverse relationship between time frame and intent.

Second, intentions may be provisional, for people are not engaged in real decision making when they complete questionnaires. Instead, a level of social desirability bias may be evident, where survey respondents give answers they think the interviewer wants to hear (Budeanu 2007). Social desirability bias has been used to explain the gap between environmental issue awareness and action where Barr (2004) observes that because certain environmental actions have become socially accepted, people will state an intent to participate, even if they have no intention of doing so. It may also be common in tourism, where a stated intent to return may be a better reflection of satisfaction than any real future behavior (Um and Chon 2006). This assertion is supported empirically by Bowen and Shoemaker (1998), Hsu (2000), and Pearce and Kang (2009), who determined that people may say they might return/repeat when in fact they have no plans to do so. In fact, Kozak, Huan, and Beaman (2002) remind us that the one certainty in tourism is that many visitors will come only once.

Volitional control is a third consideration (Conner and Armitage 1998; Sniehotta, Scholz, and Schwarzer 2005). Intentions may be valid surrogates when the person exerts complete control over the situation, but their accuracy diminishes significantly when actions are determined by factors beyond the individual’s voluntary control (Sheppard, Hartwick, and Warchaw 1998). Fourth, multiplicity of choice can reduce accuracy, something that both Lam and Hsu (2004) and Sparks (2007) discuss in tourism. Indeed, freedom of choice and wanderlust seem to be inherent in much tourism activity (Castro, Armario, and Ruiz 2007; Crompton 1979; Niininen, Szivas, and Riley 2004; Pearce and Kang 2009), causing many people to visit places one time only. Multiplicity of choice may help explain why some researchers believe past behavior is a better predictor of future behavior than intentions (Conner and Armitage 1998; Correia, Barros, and Silvestre 2007; Petrick, Morais, and Norman 2001; Venkatesh, Maruping, and Brown 2006).

Perhaps, the greatest challenge in demonstrating the link between intentions and actions, though, lies in the difficulty in distinguishing between an amorphous “desire” to do something and an actionable “probability” that something will be done. It is for this reason that Lam and Hsu (2004) and Sheppard, Hartwick, and Warchaw (1988) assert that establishing a meaningful measure of intent is the most critical issue in ensuring the validity of TRA or TPB research. Sheppard, Hartwick, and Warchaw (1988) stress the importance of measuring intention through the use of a probabilistic estimation of performance, within a specified time frame, rather than simply measuring a vague intention to do something at some time in the future. The measurement challenge is highlighted in studies examining job satisfaction, intention to quit, and actual resignation rates among health care workers (Seston et al. 2009; Soothill, Barry, and Williams 1992). This research shows a strong correlation between level of job satisfaction/dissatisfaction and intention to quit but a much weaker relationship between dissatisfaction and actual departure. A similar situation is found in a hospitality loyalty context where Bowen and Chen (2001) and Campo and Yague (2008) note the most satisfied customers are the most loyal (and hence most likely to return), but once satisfaction dips below a certain threshold, repeat propensity declines geometrically.

Finally, one must consider the unique nature of tourism that may make intentions less accurate than with other consumer goods and services. McKercher, Denizi-Guillett, and Ng (2012) reviewed the literature and noted that tourism is typified by diversity of opportunities, infrequent purchases, the democratic nature of the travel experience, a vast array of providers, little real distinction between providers, low sectoral dominance, high substitutability, and a range of other conditions. Caneem’s (2003) study of Japanese and American tourists visiting Hawaii revealed that Japanese tourists expressed high return intentions but had relatively low repeat visitation rates, while Americans stated a lower return intention but actually demonstrated much higher return rates. Mechinda, Serirat, and Guild (2009) found significant differences between domestic and international tourists, even though international tourists voiced strong intentions to return. McKercher (2009) further demonstrated empirically the impact of distance on a decaying share of repeat visitors to Hong Kong. Collectively, these conditions may mitigate against a strong correlation between intention and repetition.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: The existence and strength of the relationship between intentions to return and actual repeat visitation rates can be measured either directly or indirectly. The direct method involves the collection of primary data measuring individual tourists’ satisfaction, intent to return, and their subsequent actual behavior at some later date to determine if indeed they did return. This approach would involve conducting a longitudinal study running for many years to ensure that an accurate measure of repeat propensity could be gained. It would also necessitate an extremely large sample size to control for the inevitable participant attrition over time. Ideally, as well, it would be run in a number of settings to examine the intervening impacts of distance, time availability of tourists, domestic versus international tourism, and the like. To the authors’ knowledge, no such study has been undertaken because of the substantive logistical, time, and cost constraints involved.

The indirect method, on the other hand, involves analysis of readily available secondary data collected by national tourism organizations that measure intent to return, repeat visitation and other variables, including satisfaction, as part of their ongoing departing visitor surveys. It is possible, therefore, to gauge the relationship between these variables at an aggregate level for specific markets, or market segments surveyed. The use of these aggregate data clearly does not have the level of precision as primary data, for one has to consider that the repeat visitor market is composed of those people who intended to repeat and did, as well as those people who did not intend to return, but ultimately did. One must consider a discounting effect, then, that not all repeat visitors intended to return. It can also not consider the possible long lag time between repeat visits, something Oppermann (1998) discusses as a challenge in using repeat visitation as a metric to measure loyalty.

Analysis of secondary data is a valid method provided the survey instrument and resultant data satisfy reliability, sensitivity, fitness, and validity criteria for the desired purpose (Pizam 1994; Churchill 1995; Saunders, Lewis, and Thornhill 2000). Reliability and sensitivity criteria relate to the extent to which data can provide consistent results and fine enough detail for the purpose of the research. Fitness recognizes that data collected for one purpose may not be relevant, timely or suitable for another purpose. Validity refers to the degree to which the instrument can predict a criterion (Pizam 1994). A review of the data sets identified in this study suggests that they meet these four criteria and, in particular, address the two issues raised in the previous paragraph. First, intention to return rates are invariably high and quite stable over time. Table 2 presents longitudinal repeat intentions data over a 13-year period from a total of 30 markets that visited Hong Kong or New Zealand. The data relate exclusively to the pleasure tourist segment. Rarely did intent drop below 80%, and in many instances exceeded 95%. Moreover, intentions fluctuated in a narrow band, with the standard deviation rarely exceeding 5% of the long-term mean. Concerns about the discounting effect of nonrepeat visitors who returned can largely be resolved, as the vast majority of survey respondents intended to return.

caption.p: Longitudinal Intention to Return to Hong Kong (1998-2010) or New Zealand (1999-2011)

sec.p: Second, the share of the repeat visitors has also remained relatively stable over time and has also fluctuated in a narrow band, again suggesting that lag time is not a major concern. A review of the share of first-time tourists between 2001 and 2010 to nine destinations from 90 source markets shows relatively little year-on-year fluctuation in repeater share (Table 3), even though global and regional tourism flows fluctuated significantly during this period because of a series of crises, including 9/11, SARS, the Bali bombing, the global financial crisis, and most recently the swine flu scare. Again, repeat visitor shares tend to fluctuate narrowly, rarely exceeding 10% of the long-term mean. For example, between 2001 and 2010, the share of repeat Vacation Overnight tourists to Hong Kong from Nordic Countries ranged from a low of 23% to a high of 29%, with a mean of 26.3% and a standard deviation of 2.4%. The share of repeat pleasure tourists visiting New Zealand from Australia ranged from 46% to 55% with an average of 51.2% and a standard deviation of 4.2%. Similar patterns were noted in the Bahamas, the Cayman Islands, Ireland, Israel, South Africa, and the United States. Wider fluctuations were noted in one of two situations: either in emerging markets that showed high growth rates, or among markets with extremely low repeat propensities. For example, the emerging China and Indian markets visiting Hong Kong and to a lesser extent Australia were somewhat more volatile than others, while economies with low repeat propensities, such as China to New Zealand, also showed more volatility in repeat share.

sec.p: The relative stability in both intention and repeat visitation rates means that data from any given year approximates a “typical” case that is broadly representative of the background rate for both variables. As such, it is possible to conduct a cross-sectional analysis comparing the two figures, in addition to correlating intent and action over time.

sec.title: Data Sources
sec.p: Two data sources are used in this study. Longitudinal data were gathered from New Zealand and Hong Kong. The New Zealand data set covers the years 1999 to 2011, while the Hong Kong data set extends from 1998 to 2010. In each case, the pleasure or vacation segment has been isolated from the overall tourist population. These data include the share of repeat visitors, the proportion who intend to return and the volume of pleasure arrival numbers.

Cross-sectional data were derived from official annual visitor statistics and market intelligence reports published by 16 national tourism organizations that were available online. Participating economies and the number of markets per economy are shown in Table 4. (Note, the term economy is used in conjunction with UN World Tourism Organization guidelines, where places like Hong Kong are considered as independent “economies” for UNWTO purposes, even though they are not countries per se.) Data on intentions to return and repeat visitor share are available for 156 originating markets, while mean satisfaction data are available for 90 markets.

sec.p: The currency of the data, unit of analysis, and composition of the sample by trip purpose varies from destination to destination. In all cases, the study used the most recent available data. For the most part, these data were gathered in either 2009 or 2010. However, some of the data for Brazil were collected in 2002, while the information for the Maldives and the Turks and Caicos Islands dates from 2004. The unit of analysis also varies. Brazil, Hong Kong, New Zealand, Macedonia, and Spain report figures by country/economy of origin. Most other destinations report either a combination of individual country data and aggregate regional data, or simply aggregate data for all arrivals. Ireland, for example records individual data for the United Kingdom, France, and Germany, and aggregate information for the rest of Europe, and “other” source markets. Trinidad and Tobago record information for all visitors irrespective of their source. The United States, though, generates a large majority of visitors. The Bahamas collects data on all visitors and all stopover visitors, while the Cayman Islands reports data for all visitors and cruise visitors.

The composition of the sample by trip purpose varies by economy. New Zealand and Hong Kong identify pleasure and business tourists as discrete segments. Ireland’s data focused only on the pleasure tourism sector. Most others, though, do not make any distinction by trip purpose. Some sun, sand, and sea economies clearly attract a primarily vacation oriented market, while others attract a broader mix of pleasure, business, and VFR (visiting friends and relatives) tourists. The use of an undifferentiated trip purpose, therefore, must be viewed as a limitation of the large data set, for differences exist in intent and actual repeat visitation rates by purpose. Travel for business tourists is nondiscretionary, and more importantly, usually involves a third party, the employer, paying for the costs of the trip (Davidson and Cope 2003). Obligation may play a larger role for travel to visit friends and especially relatives (Ali and Holden 2006), which may result in both higher intention and conversion rates than with the more discretionary pleasure tourist.

It is for this reason that discrete subsets of purely business and mostly pleasure tourists were identified for further analysis. Both New Zealand and Hong Kong maintain relevant databases on business tourists. The 21 cases from these two economies represent that subset. Identifying a pleasure tourism subset was more challenging, given that a number of economies identify trip purpose but do not differentiate their aggregate data by purpose. A series of tests was undertaken using various thresholds of share of pleasure tourists to identify this segment. Consistent results occurred when the threshold for pleasure tourist share was at least 73% of arrivals. The results were less reliable when a lower threshold was used. As such, a minimum 73% or more pleasure tourist share constituted the subset of pleasure tourists to be analyzed. A total of 74 cases met this criterion.

Consistency of data represents one of the great challenges when utilizing secondary data produced by different sources. Table 5 identifies the data sources and how intention and satisfaction were measured by the respective destinations (see appendix). Twelve of the 16 economies measured intentions using a binary yes/no metric that did not state either probability or time frame. Four economies, the Bahamas, Ireland, the Maldives, and the Turks and Caicos used more specific, time-bound, probabilistic measures. For example, Ireland adopted a 7-point scale including “Definitely I’ll be back later this year” and “Definitely I’ll be back next year,” “Definitely I’ll be back in the next few years,” “I hope so—at some time in the future,” “Probably not,” “Definitely not,” and “Don’t know.” The Bahamas measured likelihood of return within a 5-year time frame, including very likely, somewhat likely, somewhat unlikely, and not likely at all. It is therefore possible to further isolate a sample of 18 cases from these four economies where analysis of a probabilistic intentions’ criterion can be assessed.

sec.p: Satisfaction was also defined and measured differently depending on the economy. In the cases of Brazil and Ireland, for example, satisfaction was inferred from the question related to whether the trip met tourists’ expectations. The Turks and Caicos Islands measured satisfaction by assessing overall value for money, while the Seychelles measured enjoyment of stay. Satisfaction levels were also presented in one of two ways. Seven economies, representing 90 markets, reported a mean score, measuring the degree of satisfaction out of 5, 10, or 100. Scores were normalized to 100 points for ease of comparison. Another five economies reported satisfaction on a Likert-type scale (percentage very satisfied, percentage satisfied, etc). These data were not included in the study, as it was difficult to compare mean with Likert-scale questions absolutely. As a result, satisfaction measures are limited to the 90 cases where mean satisfaction was used.

Other limitations inherent in the data must be acknowledged. The study relies on secondary data produced by a small number of NTOs, some of which are dated. A number of the destinations are small island economies, or in the cases of Brazil and Macedonia, emerging destinations. The most popular destinations in Western Europe, North America, and to a lesser extent, Asia are not included because of lack of data availability. As a result, this study can be classified as exploratory in nature.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Correlation tests were conducted on the two data sets. The first set of analyses relates to the longitudinal data from Hong Kong and New Zealand. The second part of this section presents the findings for the full set of 156 cases, plus three subsets of data—the business tourist, the pleasure tourist, and a small group of pleasure tourists where intention was measured using a probabilistic metric.

sec.title: Longitudinal Data—Pleasure Tourists to Hong Kong and New Zealand
sec.p: Data covering a 13-year period from 30 pleasure tourist markets that visited either Hong Kong or New Zealand are examined first. Two sets of correlation analyses were undertaken. The first examined the relationship of one year’s intentions with the following year’s repeat visitation levels (i.e., 2009 intentions with 2010 repeat visitor rates). The second assessed intentions from one year with repeat visitor rates for the same year (i.e., 2009 intentions with 2009 repeat visitor levels). This second analysis was conducted to test the validity of cross-sectional analysis. If these results were largely similar to the results of the tests comparing intentions with the subsequent year’s repeat rates, then one could argue that cross-sectional analysis is valid. If the results were divergent, then the use of cross-sectional method could be questioned. The results are presented in Table 6.

sec.p: No statistically significant correlation was noted between intention to return and the following year’s share of repeat visitors for 28 of the 30 markets tested. These findings suggest that intentions and repeat propensity are not related, at least at an aggregate scale. Two exceptions were noted. A strong, positive correlation was noted with the emerging Indian pleasure tourist market visiting Hong Kong. However, the situation was not evident among other emerging markets, including China, South Africa, Central and South America, and the Middle East. One must be cautious, therefore, about inferring a link between intentions and actions among emerging markets. Conversely, and somewhat ironically, an even stronger inverse correlation was noted between intentions and repeat visitation share among Canadian tourists visiting Hong Kong. Again, this situation was not noted elsewhere among mature markets.

The tests on same-year data also revealed no statistically significant correlation between intentions and actions for any of the 30 markets tested. As such, the cross-sectional correlations proved to be no more or no less robust that measuring intentions and arrivals in different years, with the aforementioned exceptions of India and Canada, where the results proved contradictory.

sec.title: Cross-sectional Data
sec.p: Three groups or subgroups of the cross-sectional data were analyzed. To begin, the full data set of 156 cases was examined. Then, the authors examined the subset of pleasure tourists, followed by the business tourists, respectively. The pleasure subset of 73 cases was analyzed first using the more generic or vague intentions metric, defined either using binary responses (from 12 destinations) or a loose definition when intent was measured more precisely from four markets that assessed it on a scale. For example, Ireland uses a 5-point scale. This study adopted the three positive answers ranging from “I hope so—sometime in the future,” “I’ll be back next year,” and “Definitely I’ll be back later this year.” A second analysis was conducted using much tighter conditions specified by the Bahamas, Ireland, the Maldives, and the Turks and Caicos, where intent was assessed on the basis of respondents’ highest probability of returning within a short time frame. For example, in the case of Ireland, the response “Definitely I’ll be back later this year” was used. The sample for this group is limited to 18 cases.

Tables 7 to 10 present the results of the correlation analyses for the entire sample, and the subsets of pleasure and business tourists, respectively, while Figure 1 presents a scattergraph visualizing the relationship between intention and repeat visitation rates for the pleasure tourist segments. Three variables are tested, including the percentage of repeat visitors, satisfaction levels, the distance between the destination and the major outbound gateway measured in 1,000-km increments. The distance dimension was used by McKercher, Chan, and Lam (2008) in their global study of the impact of distance on tourism demand.

sec.p: Table 7 reports the findings for the full data set of 156 cases. No statistically significant relationship is noted between the share of repeat visitors and intention to return. However, a statistically significant relationship was observed between distance traveled and intent to return, indicating that the further the individual traveled the more likely he or she expressed a desire to return. Robust inverse relationships were also noted between repeat visitor share and both satisfaction and distance.

The positive associations between distance and desire to return, coupled with the inverse relationship between distance and actual repeat visitation rates are understandable, given the extensive literature on the impact of distance on demand (McKercher, Chan, and Lam 2008). Distance is also associated with greater variety-seeking behavior (Pearce and Lee 2005) and the aspirational, often one-off nature of long-haul travel (Yeoman and Lederer 2005), which reflects both higher satisfaction and lower repeat visitation (Hong et al. 2009). The relationship between satisfaction and repeat visitation seems to be intuitively illogical, on the surface. But it must be remembered that overall satisfaction rates were high, across the board. Thus, the observed relationship has more to do with degree of satisfaction than with a satisfaction–dissatisfaction split. Perhaps, once the “wow” factor of visiting new places passes, repeat visitors may become more aware of a destination’s limitations. Remember, Oppermann (1999) reminds us that much of repeat visitation, especially to nearby destinations, can be attributed to habituation rather than loyalty, with the habitual visitor likely be less satisfied.

Results for the subset of pleasure tourists are presented in Tables 8 and 9 and Figure 1. Table 8 and Figure 1 present the findings for sample of 73 pleasure tourism cases where a generic or nonspecific intention to return was measured. Table 9 isolates the 18 cases from four economies where a specific, time-bound, and probabilistic intention was measured. A near random relationship exists between intention and actual repeat propensity when intention is measured imprecisely. Invariably, a high vague intention to return was recorded, typically 85% of the sample or more, while actual repeat visitation rates were typically lower than 40% of arrivals. Likewise, no statistically significant relationship was observed between intention to return and satisfaction, although it was correlated positively with distance. However, once more an inverse relationship is noted between the share of repeat visitors and both distance and satisfaction.

A different story emerges when intention is measured using more rigorous criteria that attempt to assess the probability of repeating. The sample is small, so the results must be considered as being indicative. But, here, a significant positive correlation is noted between intent and actual repeat visitation rates, while intent and distance are negatively correlated. This finding suggests that long-haul travelers may desire to return (Table 8), but when asked about the probability of returning they adopt a more pragmatic position and recognize that the chances of doing so are slight. The inclusion of both likelihood and a specified time frame have the combined effect of forcing respondents to differentiate between an aspirational though vague desire to revisit and a realistic likelihood that they will visit again.

Finally, Table 10 presents the findings for the sample of business tourists visiting Hong Kong and New Zealand. Again, no significant correlation was noted between intention and actual repeat visitation rate. Intention was correlated strongly and positively with satisfaction, while repeat propensity was inversely correlated with both distance and satisfaction.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article asked if intent to return was a valid surrogate measure for actual repeat visitation. In the absence of primary data, the authors analyzed two sets of secondary data (longitudinal and cross-sectional) to explore this question. The findings raise many questions about the existence of such a relationship, at least at an aggregate level, for little evidence that the two metrics were correlated was noted. In particular, the common method of measuring a vague intent on a binary scale, adopted by most national tourism organizations, and apparently in many loyalty and satisfaction studies, proved to be unreliable. The use of a probabilistic, time-based measure of intent produced more reliable results, but as the data suggest, even this measure’s accuracy deteriorates with distance traveled. The findings challenge many of the assumptions about the validity of revisit intentions, and in doing so also question the validity of applying findings from research conducted in a nontourism setting to the unique situation of tourism, where choice, wanderlust, infrequent purchase, and distance combine to erode the accuracy of this measure.

While this study raises some fundamental questions about the relationship between intentions and actions, it does so only at an aggregate level. We cannot comment on the actions of individual tourists. Clearly, some, and possibly, many tourists who intend to return will become repeat visitors. But, equally as clearly, not all will. The literature suggests that developing an accurate measure of strength of intention is most critical, even though it can be modified by distance, time lag, and a range of other factors. Perhaps, more than anything else, this study highlights the need to conduct dedicated longitudinal research that focuses on the behavioral intentions and actions of individual tourists over time to verify or refute these findings. But given the lack of such data, the authors do caution that intention is, at best, an imprecise indicator of repeat propensity that overstates the actual number of repeat visitors significantly.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Bob McKercher is a Professor of Tourism in the School of Hotel and Tourism Management, at The Hong Kong Polytechnic University. He has wide ranging research interests, including challenging some of the accepted myths about tourism.

Tony SM Tse is Assistant Professor and Programme Director (Industry Partnerships) at The Hong Kong Polytechnic University’s School of Hotel & Tourism Management. Dr Tse teaches subjects including Marketing, Aviation Policy, and Professional Development. In addition, he is responsible for administering executive education, consultancy services, and student internships at the School.
